title: Problem Statement
content: Erdős Problem #434 asks: Which k-element subset of {1,...,n} maximizes the count of non-representable integers? Kiss (2002) proved the answer is {n-k+1,...,n} (the 'top k' set).

title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import Mathlib's multiset operations (for sums with repetition), set cardinality, and GCD theory. These provide the foundation for defining representability and counting non-representables.

title: Representability
content: A number n is representable by set A if n can be written as a sum of elements from A, with repetition allowed. We formalize this using multisets: n = a₁ + a₂ + ... + aₘ where each aᵢ ∈ A.

title: Zero is Representable
content: Zero is always representable by any set—use the empty multiset. This is the base case: the empty sum equals 0.

title: Elements are Representable
content: Any element of A is representable: just take the singleton multiset containing that element. Its sum is itself.

title: Sum of Representables
content: If m and n are both representable by A, then m + n is also representable. Combine the two multisets—the sum of sums is the sum of the combined multiset.

title: Non-Representable Set
content: The set of non-representable integers: all n ∈ ℕ such that n cannot be written as a sum of elements from A. This is the complement of the representable integers.

title: Counting Non-Representables
content: We define both encard (extended natural, may be infinite) and ncard (natural) counts. When gcd(A) > 1, infinitely many integers are non-representable; when gcd(A) = 1, the count is finite.

title: Frobenius Number
content: The Frobenius number of A is the LARGEST non-representable integer. For coprime a, b, Sylvester proved this equals ab - a - b. Problem #434 asks about COUNT, not maximum.

title: Complete Sets
content: A set is 'complete' if gcd(A) = 1. Such sets have only finitely many non-representable integers. The Chicken McNugget theorem is a famous example: {6, 9, 20} gives Frobenius number 43.

title: The topK Set
content: topK(n, k) = {n-k+1, n-k+2, ..., n}—the k largest integers in {1,...,n}. This is the conjectured (and proved) optimal choice for maximizing non-representables.

title: topK Has k Elements
content: When k ≤ n and k > 0, the set topK(n,k) contains exactly k elements. This is the interval [n-k+1, n] which has n - (n-k+1) + 1 = k elements.

title: Extremal Frobenius Question
content: The formal question: for any k-element subset A of {1,...,n}, is nCardNonRepresentable(A) ≤ nCardNonRepresentable(topK(n,k))? Kiss proved: YES.

title: Example: {2, 3}
content: With A = {2, 3}, the only non-representable positive integer is 1. We can make 2=2, 3=3, 4=2+2, 5=2+3, 6=3+3, and all larger integers. Frobenius number is 1.

title: Example: {3, 5}
content: With A = {3, 5}, non-representables are {1, 2, 4, 7}. The Frobenius number is 7. By Sylvester: 3·5 - 3 - 5 = 7. Count: (3-1)(5-1)/2 = 4.

title: Example: topK(5,2) = {4,5}
content: With n=5, k=2, we get topK = {4, 5}. Non-representables include 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 11, and many more. Compare to {1, 2} where only 0 is non-representable!

title: Kiss's Theorem (2002)
content: **KEY RESULT**: For any 1 ≤ k ≤ n, the set {n-k+1,...,n} maximizes the count of non-representable integers among all k-element subsets of {1,...,n}. This is axiomatized as the proof requires deep analysis.

title: Problem Answer
content: The answer to Erdős Problem #434 is YES: the topK set is optimal. This follows directly from Kiss's theorem.

title: Larger Numbers Create Gaps
content: Intuition: If A contains 1, almost everything is representable. If A contains only large numbers like {9, 10}, many small integers (1-8) plus gaps (11-17, etc.) are non-representable.

title: Sylvester-Frobenius Theorem
content: For coprime a, b > 0, the Frobenius number is ab - a - b. This classical 1884 result gives an explicit formula for two elements. For {3,5}: 3·5-3-5 = 7.

title: Sylvester Count Formula
content: For coprime a, b, the COUNT of non-representables is (a-1)(b-1)/2. For {3,5}: (2)(4)/2 = 4. This count grows quadratically as a, b increase.

title: Consecutive Integers
content: For consecutive integers n-1, n (always coprime), the count is (n-2)(n-1)/2. This grows quadratically with n, showing why larger numbers give more non-representables.

title: Greedy Construction
content: The greedy approach: always pick the largest available number. This produces exactly the topK set and is optimal. Intuition: large numbers enable fewer representations.

title: Finiteness of Non-Representables
content: When gcd(A) = 1 (A is 'complete'), the set of non-representables is finite. For topK(n,k) with k ≥ 2, gcd is often 1, ensuring finitely many non-representables.

title: Connection to Problem #433
content: Problem #433 asks about Frobenius numbers for {n, n+1, ..., n+k-1} (consecutive starting at n). Problem #434 asks which subset of {1,...,n} maximizes COUNT. Related but distinct questions.

title: Complete Answer
content: **FINAL RESULT**: For all n ≥ 1, k ≥ 1, k ≤ n: the set {n-k+1, ..., n} maximizes nCardNonRepresentable among all k-element subsets of {1,...,n}. Kiss (2002) proved this.

title: topK Achieves Maximum
content: Corollary formulation: topK(n,k) is the unique (up to edge cases) set achieving the maximum count of non-representable integers.
